author: By Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
title: Shock, Glee and Unease as Syrians Celebrate the Unthinkable
description: A day after the regime of President Bashar al-Assad fell, civilians poured into the streets of Damascus, weeping in disbelief. Many sought word of relatives held in a notorious prison on the outskirts of the city.
content: Syrian security checkpoints sat empty on Monday across Damascus. Abandoned tanks were scattered across the roads, along with stray pieces of military uniforms stripped off by soldiers when opposition forces stormed into the city a day earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Sipher and Michael V. Hayden
title: Running Spies Is Not a Game for Amateurs
description: Will Trump be satisfied with servile leadership, or is he seeking to dismantle the system and make agencies responsive to his demands?
content: President-elect Donald Trump’s promises to destroy what he calls the “deep state” predate his first term in the White House. The sentiment raises fears in the intelligence community that there will be purges of career professionals, and that intelligence designed to protect American lives will be twisted to fit Mr. Trump’s personal interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Give Your Salmon an Anchovy Butter Boost
description: In my five-star salmon dinner, anchovies lend their intense and pungent bite to the sweet pink fillets.
content: Of all the ways to add oomph to weeknight cooking, the one I turn to most is anchovies. Honestly, I add them to pretty much everything short of ice cream, and I’ll go double if fish is on the menu. Tossing a couple of salty, saline anchovies into a pan of salmon or hake fillets is an easy move to bring out a deep umami funk that’s earthy rather than fishy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why Street Vendors Are Upset About a Ballot Measure
description: Proposition 2, which gives the Sanitation Department more authority to conduct sweeps of vendors, will hit immigrant vendors hard, an advocacy group said.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at some concerns from street vendors about Proposition 2, one of the ballot measures approved by New York City voters last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
title: Ukraine Asks if Telegram, Its Favorite App, Is a Sleeper Agent
description: The messaging app’s popularity has soared during the war with Russia, leading Ukrainian officials to increasingly weigh Telegram’s upsides against its security risks.
content: In the nearly three years since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the messaging app Telegram has been a lifeline for millions of Ukrainians. It provides information about coming attacks and helps communities organize food, medical aid and other support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Pardon You
description: Who among us deserves a get-out-of-jail-free card?
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Do you think it would be a good idea if Joe Biden gave presidential pardons to us in advance — as well as anyone else Donald Trump might go after once he’s back in office?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muhammad Haj Kadour and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Syrians Displaced by War Rush to Return Home
description: The 13-year conflict in Syria caused one of the “largest displacement crises in the world,” according to the United Nations. Now, an untold number of people are trying to go back.
content: When Abdo Bakri returned to his hometown in northwestern Syria on Saturday after more than five years roaming the area in search of safe shelter for his family during the country’s civil war, he did not know what he would find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Eases Overall Monetary Policy Stance for First Time in 14 Years
description: Faced with a faltering economy and falling prices, the Politburo loosened the policy approach of China’s central bank and called for “extraordinary” measures.
content: China’s ruling Politburo loosened the country’s overall monetary policy on Monday for the first time in 14 years, the latest in a series of measures aimed at recharging economic growth and stopping a broad decline in prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj
title: India’s Luxury Property Market Is a Boon to Trump’s Business
description: The Trump Organization finds a warm welcome in India, where status-hungry home buyers clamor for a famous American brand.
content: When Donald J. Trump started his first campaign for the presidency, two Trump-branded buildings were going up in India, one in the financial capital of Mumbai and the other nearby in Pune. Before he won in 2016, the Trump Organization expanded its business in India, signing deals in two more big cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: How to Keep Your Own Soul Safe in the Dark
description: Even at my lowest, I have never entirely given up my faith that good people working together can change the world for the better.
content: A few days before Thanksgiving, my husband and I finally moved our indoor plants back indoors. In years past we brought them inside in late September, just to be safe, because in those days frost often fell in early October, and a killing freeze inevitably came by the end of the month. This year, the first killing freeze finally came on Nov. 30, our latest first freeze in history. My indoor plants have become outdoor plants for all but four months of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Elaine May Makes a Rare Appearance to Talk About ‘Mikey and Nicky’
description: At a screening of the gangster tale starring Peter Falk and John Cassavetes, the director recalls her battle with Paramount to get the film released.
content: At Metrograph theater on Friday, a crowd of around 175 people was treated to the cinephile’s equivalent of a Bigfoot sighting on the Lower East Side: A rare public appearance by the 92-year-old writer, director and actress Elaine May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jay-Z, Accused in Suit of Raping Minor With Sean Combs, Calls It Blackmail
description: The entertainer said the suit, which accuses him of assaulting an unnamed 13-year-old girl in 2000, was an effort to gain settlement money by putting forward “idiotic” claims.
content: Jay-Z was accused of raping a 13-year-old girl with Sean Combs in a lawsuit filed Sunday by an unnamed plaintiff. He vehemently denied the allegation and accused the lawyer who brought the suit of trying to blackmail him with false claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Mahler and Jim Rutenberg
title: Rupert Murdoch Fails in Bid to Change Family Trust
description: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Mr. Murdoch, who was trying to give full control of his empire to his son Lachlan and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant.
content: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Rupert Murdoch’s attempt to change his family’s trust to consolidate his eldest son Lachlan’s control of his media empire and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant, according to a sealed court document obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Three-Quarters of Earth’s Land Got Drier in Recent Decades, U.N. Says
description: Human-caused global warming helped increase dry conditions on every continent, scientists said in a new report, as talks on halting desertification were underway in Saudi Arabia.
content: From the American West to eastern China, more than three-quarters of Earth’s land became persistently drier in recent decades, according to a new United Nations report that called the shift a “global, existential peril.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Graham Dickie
title: Spying on Student Devices, Schools Aim to Intercept Self-Harm Before It Happens
description: New technology alerts schools when students type words related to suicide. But do the timely interventions balance out the false alarms?
content: Dawn was still hours away when Angel Cholka was awakened by the beams of a police flashlight through the window. At the door was an officer, who asked if someone named Madi lived there. He said he needed to check on her. Ms. Cholka ran to her 16-year-old’s bedroom, confused and, suddenly, terrified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: This Race Was Decided by 734 Votes. The G.O.P. Wants to Disqualify 60,000 Ballots.
description: One of the closest state elections in North Carolina history now hinges on the latest power struggle between state Republicans and Democrats — and a voter form dating back 20 years.
content: From voter ID laws to district map-drawing to judges redeciding cases, North Carolina has long been a laboratory of sorts in ways to amass political power. In recent years, Republicans in particular have changed both state laws and election rules to hamstring Democrats’ influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
title: Syrian Military Officials Charged With War Crimes as Government Falls
description: The officials, Jamil Hassan and Abdul Salam Mahmoud, ran an infamous prison in Damascus and “sought to terrify, intimidate and repress any opposition, or perceived opposition, to the regime,” according to the indictment.
content: The Justice Department has charged two top Syrian military officials with war crimes committed against Americans and others at a notorious prison in Damascus during the Syrian civil war, according to an indictment unsealed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Best Theater of 2024
description: Broadway roared back, but the kitties were downtown and the prayer service was in Brooklyn.
content: Broadway always looks its healthiest around the holidays, and indeed, right now, most of its 41 theaters are lit, with the rest soon set to load in new tenants. Box office grosses, if not quite back to prepandemic levels, seem likely to meet or exceed last year’s $1.6 billion. But the real health of the commercial theater, for me, is demonstrated by how much it offers its audiences, not its investors. That’s why, most years, my list of best shows is top-heavy with the provocative work being brewed Off Broadway. If my latest list tilts the other way, perhaps that reflects Broadway’s liberal borrowings from the noncommercial sector — borrowings and often improvements. My Top 10, listed chronologically and covering the period from December 2023 through the end of November, are therefore mostly shows that, wherever they started and wherever they wind up, put a premium on provocation, sure, but also entertainment. That’s what I call healthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Erica L. Green
title: Activists Call on Biden to Clear Death Row Before Trump Takes Office
description: The series of open letters from human rights activists and former corrections officials aligned with a larger push from Democrats for sweeping clemency action for those in prison.
content: A group of human rights activists, former corrections officials and families of crime victims asked President Biden on Monday to use his clemency power to take all 40 inmates off federal death row before he hands over power to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattia Ferraresi
title: She Won Over Italy. Now She’s Bringing Trumpism to Europe.
description: Giorgia Meloni is ready to be the bridge between Donald Trump and Europe.
content: Unless Donald Trump decides to communicate with European allies solely in the acerbic language of tariffs, he will have to address the famous question usually attributed to Henry Kissinger: Who do I call when I want to talk to Europe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Police Arrested a ‘Strong Person of Interest’ in Killing of C.E.O.
description: Also, rebels asserted control in Syria. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: After a five-day manhunt, police arrested a man today in connection with the brazen killing of a health insurance executive last week in Midtown Manhattan. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Best Songs of 2024
description: Listen to 68 tracks that made major statements, boosted big beefs, propelled up-and-comers and soundtracked the party this year.
content: Here’s a dipperful of worthwhile tracks from the ocean of music released this year. The top of my list is big-statement songs, ones that had repercussions beyond how they sound. Below those, it’s not a ranking but a playlist, a more-or-less guided cruise through what 2024 sounded like for one avid listener. I didn’t include any songs from my list of top albums, which are worth hearing from start to finish. But in the multiverse of streaming music, there are plenty of other possibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tricia Tisak
title: 24 Things That Happened for the First Time in 2024
description: A series of surprising milestones, events and trends that were unprecedented until now.
content: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Bars President From Traveling Abroad
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol cannot leave the country as an investigation unfolds into whether he led an insurrection last week when he briefly imposed martial law.
content: South Korea’s political dysfunction deepened Monday as its Ministry of Justice barred President Yoon Suk Yeol from leaving the country while officials investigate whether his brief declaration of martial law last week amounted to leading an insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: An Elite School and the Criminal It Hired to Teach Math
description: Saint Ann’s School hired Winston Nguyen knowing he had been imprisoned for fraud. Then someone began soliciting graphic sexual images from its students.
content: Less than a month into Winston Nguyen’s teaching career at Saint Ann’s, an elite private school in Brooklyn, his eighth-grade students discovered that he was a felon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: A Test for the System
description: Donald Trump will take office with weakened checks on his power.
content: When the makers of “Schoolhouse Rock” set out in the 1970s to explain how the federal government works, they likened it to a three-ring circus. It was more than just a comment on the chaos of Washington — it was a metaphor for the three coequal branches of government that make our democracy what it is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Masha Goncharova
title: Events to Shake, or Gently Rattle, the World in 2025
description: Planning your calendar for next year? Here are some events to look out for.
content: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: What Syria Needs in Order to Rebuild
description: U.S. sanctions policy in the country must change.
content: After more than a decade of war, everything about Syria’s political landscape has changed in the space of 72 hours. Now U.S. sanctions policy must change with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: E.P.A. Bans Cancer-Causing Chemicals Used in Dry Cleaning
description: The two solvents, known as Perc and TCE, cause kidney cancer and other ailments, and have been the subject of years of controversy.
content: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday banned two solvents found in everyday products that can cause cancer and other serious diseases. It was a move long sought by environmental and health advocates, even as they braced for what could be a wave of deregulation by the incoming Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Who Is Alina Habba, the Lawyer Trump Picked to Serve as Counselor to the President?
description: Ms. Habba, who has advised the president-elect on legal matters in recent years, offered fiery defenses of him during his civil fraud trial in New York.
content: Alina Habba, who President-elect Donald J. Trump said would serve as a counselor to the president in the White House during his second term, has advised him on legal matters since he left office in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Arts Patron Aims to Help Underrepresented Museum Professionals
description: Allison Berg has established a foundation to elevate the careers of six emerging visual arts curators, educators and administrators each year.
content: In the fall of 2020, the arts patron Allison Berg listened to the book “From Generosity to Justice: A New Gospel of Wealth” by the Ford Foundation president Darren Walker. She had what she called a lightbulb moment, “hearing Darren speak to the difference between band-aiding a problem and actually taking action to influence systemic change toward equity and justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Massacre in Haiti’s Capital Leaves Nearly 200 Dead, U.N. Says
description: The killings in a Port-au-Prince slum, which appeared to target practitioners of Voodoo, were ordered by a gang leader, a Haitian human rights organization said.
content: More than 180 people were killed in a massacre over the weekend in one of the poorest neighborhoods of Haiti’s capital, the United Nations’ human rights chief said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Dune: Prophecy’: Travis Fimmel on His Character’s Fiery Rise to the Top
description: Desmond Hart has been a wild card since he burned a young prince alive with his mind. The actor who plays him talked about what motivates Desmond’s drive for power.
content: This interview contains mild spoilers for Season 1, Episode 4 of “Dune: Prophecy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: Matea Gold Named Washington Editor of The New York Times
description: Ms. Gold, a managing editor at The Washington Post, is the latest in a series of high-profile departures from the paper.
content: Matea Gold, a managing editor at The Washington Post who until recently was a contender for the newspaper’s top editing role, is joining The New York Times as a senior editor in its Washington bureau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Asks Court to Temporarily Freeze Sale-or-Ban Law
description: The company is requesting a pause on a law that requires the app to be sold or face a ban in the United States by mid-January, aiming to buy time for the Supreme Court or the incoming Trump administration to rescue it.
content: TikTok asked a federal court on Monday to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a ban in the United States, as it looked to the Supreme Court and the incoming Trump administration to rescue it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Danielle Kaye
title: Two Major Ad Agencies to Merge, Creating Global Giant
description: If successful, Omnicom and Interpublic would become the largest advertising company in the world, with more than $25 billion in combined revenue.
content: Omnicom Group, one of the world’s largest advertising agencies, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Interpublic Group, a large rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: After N.R.A.’s Supreme Court Win, a Dispute Over Key Facts
description: The Supreme Court’s ruling in favor of the N.R.A. in May hinged on a secret meeting involving a New York regulator. The participants say it didn’t happen.
content: Earlier this year, the sharply divided Supreme Court came together to decide unanimously in favor of the National Rifle Association. The N.R.A., the justices ruled, could pursue its claim that a New York State regulator had infringed on its First Amendment rights when she sought to discourage insurers and banks from doing business with the gun group after the 2018 school massacre in Parkland, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour
title: Crowds Throng to Prison in Syria, Desperate to Find Relatives and Friends
description: The Assad regime ran a network of torture centers that swallowed up tens of thousands of Syrians. Now that the rebels have opened the gates, many see a chance to learn of the detainees’ fates.
content: Crowds descended on a prison on the outskirts of Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Monday, desperate to learn the fate of friends and relatives detained at a place that symbolized terror and death under the regime of President Bashar al-Assad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: How Some Voters Moved From Bernie Sanders to Donald Trump
description: For some young men in particular, the populist pitches from Mr. Sanders and Mr. Trump aligned with their attitudes about the ruling class.
content: They feel frustrated by the status quo, and they’re fed up with the system. They don’t trust politicians, and they want revolutionary change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: How Old Is Too Old to Be President? Democrats Still Don’t Want to Say.
description: At a gathering of Democratic governors, many were reluctant to discuss the issue that sank President Biden’s campaign: age. Others are ready for a Gen X president.
content: Voters long believed that President Biden was too old to seek a second term. The issue torpedoed his campaign and saddled his vice president with an extraordinarily short political runway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Turns Down Cases on Admissions, Gender Identity and Guns
description: Conservative justices voiced objections and concerns about the court’s failures to take up a series of cases on major social controversies.
content: The Supreme Court on Monday turned away cases on admissions policies, gender identity and gun control, eliciting objections from conservative justices that suggested rifts on the court about whether and when to address major questions left open by recent decisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Anne Brown
title: What Kind of Cat Litter Is Best for the Planet?
description: We’ve got the scoop on traditional clay box fillers and the alternatives.
content: House training cats is easy. Most will use a litter box instinctively before they’re a month old. But what’s the environmental cost of the litter they’ll need over the years?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: How to Multiply the Power of Women and Girls in Africa
description: CAMFED combines skills training with basic education for girls, a proven model for helping them lift themselves and their communities.
content: I got my start in journalism in Kenya. Before I became a reporter I spent more than a year as a volunteer teacher in a classroom for children who couldn’t afford real school. I had arrived in the town of Machakos, an hour outside of Nairobi, determined to teach the kids who spent their days begging outside the supermarket. I realized that there was a Kenyan teacher, Alex Zakayo Mutiso, who was already doing that, so I became his unpaid intern. Every morning, I walked the dusty red roads to his classroom at the top of a hill, where the children came for the bowls of githeri, a dish made with corn and beans, but stayed to learn how to read and write.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A waterfront house in Richmond, a midcentury modern home in Pasadena and a Spanish-style residence in Santa Barbara.
content: This four-bedroom, three-and-a-half bathroom house, made of steel, concrete and walls of glass, is in the Brickyard Cove neighborhood, once home to the Richmond Brick Company. Directly on the San Francisco Bay, the house has a large private dock and a smaller one for guests, and both the nearby Brickyard Marina and the Richmond Yacht Club are easily reachable by boat. A brewery is a five-minute drive, as are a handful of convenience stores, while downtown Berkeley takes 25 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Critical Minerals Embargo Is Even Tougher Than Expected
description: Beijing ordered companies around the world not to allow critical minerals mined in China to reach the U.S., while deepening its efforts to replace imports with domestic products.
content: Alarm is rising among multinational companies doing business with China about Beijing’s decision last week to order a trade embargo on the export of four critical minerals to the United States. The central subject of concern is a provision extending the ban to companies in other countries that transfer minerals to American firms after acquiring them from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Yu
title: To Become a Better Runner, Should You Adjust Your Form?
description: Many runners believe their natural stride could be improved. Here’s what to know before trying to change yours.
content: Want to get better at tennis? Fine-tune your serve. Swimming? Perfect your stroke. But what about running? If you improve your form — from your posture to the way your foot hits the ground — will that make you faster and more efficient?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Chinese Carmakers Are Taking Mexico by Storm While Eyeing U.S.
description: BYD and other manufacturers are importing cars from China and scouting factory sites in Mexico as part of a global expansion that, for now, excludes the United States.
content: Behind a crumbling brick wall in a working-class neighborhood of Mexico City lurks a seemingly innocuous car lot. But it could be a sign of a potentially grave threat to the North American auto industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: How a Realtors’ Nonprofit Quietly Funds Conservative Advocacy Groups
description: The National Association of Realtors has created a nonprofit that gives more heavily to one side of the political aisle and to groups that have little to do with real estate and housing.
content: The National Association of Realtors — the largest trade organization in the United States — wields substantial influence over the American housing industry. To help hold on to that power, it also runs one of the biggest political action committees, routinely outspending even major companies like Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Trump Gives Powell a Reprieve, but Pledges Big Moves Elsewhere
description: The president-elect said he would not try to replace the Federal Reserve chair, but would seek to cut immigration, impose tariffs and more.
content: President-elect Donald Trump used his first broadcast interview since the election to promise a fast-moving and disruptive administration that could shake up American and global business, including raising tariffs and cutting immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: One of Japan’s Great Sushi Masters Is Working, Quietly, in Manhattan
description: To little fanfare, Keiji Nakazawa is sweating the details of the exacting Edomae tradition at Sushi Sho in Midtown.
content: An iron law of sushi holds that the more impressive the restaurant, the smaller the sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: U.S. Investigating Child Labor Claim at HelloFresh Subsidiary
description: The Labor Department investigation focuses on a plant in Aurora, Ill., operated by Factor75, a meal kit delivery company that HelloFresh acquired in 2020.
content: The U.S. Labor Department is investigating allegations that migrant children have worked at a meal preparation delivery facility in Illinois that is a subsidiary of the popular meal kit company HelloFresh, the company and federal regulators said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hogla Enecia Pérez and Frances Robles
title: Desperate Haitians Who Fled to the Dominican Republic Are Being Sent Back in Cages
description: Relations between the neighboring countries on the island of Hispaniola have long been frosty. They are now complicated by up to 10,000 deportations a week.
content: Cage-like trucks fitted with iron bars that appear designed to carry livestock line up every morning at the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Jeffers
title: Nobody Is Coming to Save Us
description: The fine artist and illustrator Oliver Jeffers on climate change, A.I. and the idea that maybe everything is pretty much our fault.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Golden Globes 2025 Snubs and Surprises: Danielle Deadwyler, ‘The Substance’ and More
description: Female directors were well-represented, while “Dune: Part Two” and “Sing Sing” didn’t do as well as expected.
content: The 82nd Golden Globes nominations were announced Monday morning and the unconventional musical “Emilia Pérez” had plenty to sing about: The Netflix film topped all movies with 10 nominations, followed by “The Brutalist” and “Conclave.” Here are some of the most notable takeaways from this year’s field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: A historic transition of power in Syria.
content: In a stunning fall, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has fled to Russia, state media there and two Iranian officials said yesterday, after he lost his hold on power to a lightning fast offensive by rebels. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Call
description: One call to a very unusual hotline, and everything that followed.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Trump Picks Former Ambassador to Mexico for Deputy Secretary of State
description: Christopher Landau is a longtime lawyer and the son of a veteran U.S. diplomat who served as ambassador to three nations in Latin America.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Sunday that he had picked Christopher Landau, a lawyer and former ambassador to Mexico, to be the deputy secretary of state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Why Chinese Americans Have Shifted Rightward
description: A growing number of Chinese Americans, especially naturalized immigrants, say Democrats have become too lenient on crime and homelessness.
content: For the three decades after she became an American citizen, Annie Tan tried to stay out of the fray. Politics, she thought, was for politicians, not for “regular people” like her, a 71-year-old Chinese American immigrant from Taiwan living in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,270
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 10, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Can I Make Corduroy Look Cool?
description: A reader seeks advice on how to style corduroy in a modern fashion. Our critic offers guidance on wearing the highly versatile fabric.
content: Corduroy is one of those materials that have been with us for so long that it has acquired a whole encyclopedia’s worth of cultural references.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: 3-D Mammograms Are Overtaking Traditional Scans. But Are They Better?
description: Here’s how good the tests are at detecting cancer and preventing false positive results.
content: Women going in for routine mammograms are increasingly being screened with a new type of imaging tool: digital breast tomosynthesis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Why I Still Send Holiday Cards — and You Should, Too
description: They serve a social function that’s surprisingly important.
content: With every Christmas card I write, I’m dreaming of a white Christmas, but I’m also pondering “The Strength of Weak Ties,” a seminal 1973 paper by the sociologist Mark Granovetter, then of Johns Hopkins University, now of Stanford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: A Quick Arab Pivot: From Welcoming al-Assad to Managing the Chaos
description: Only weeks ago, Arab nations had been working hard to bring Bashar al-Assad back into the fold, assuming he was there to last. They were badly mistaken.
content: Only weeks ago, Sunni Arab nations, led by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, were trying to bring President Bashar al-Assad of Syria back into the fold, urging him to break with a weakened Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: My Last Column: Finding Hope in an Age of Resentment
description: Where have all the good vibes gone?
content: This is my final column for The New York Times, where I began publishing my opinions in January 2000. I’m retiring from The Times, not the world, so I’ll still be expressing my views in other places. But this does seem like a good occasion to reflect on what has changed over these past 25 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: Stephanie Koenig and Her Three Rings
description: Two proposals, a wedding and three family heirlooms later, the co-star of Hulu’s “English Teacher” is learning to love jewelry.
content: In the car on the way to her first proposal, Stephanie Koenig, who stars in “English Teacher” on Hulu, asked her soon-to-be fiancé, Chris Riggi, “You’re not proposing, are you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Revolutions Swept the Middle East in 2011. Will Syria’s End Differently?
description: Bashar al-Assad’s downfall evokes memories of uprisings in Egypt, Libya, Tunisia and Yemen, each of which brought civil war or authoritarian rule. Syrians hope for better.
content: When protesters started trying in 2011 to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, they were part of a cascade of revolutions, known as the Arab Spring, that aimed to oust authoritarian leaders across the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
title: France’s First Big #MeToo Case Goes to Trial
description: The actress Adèle Haenel has accused the director Christophe Ruggia of grooming and sexually assaulting her when she was 12. If found guilty, he faces up to a decade in prison.
content: She accused him of isolating her during rehearsals and filming. Of grooming her for three years, when on Saturday afternoons he would touch her sexually. When it began, he was 36. She was 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman and Ronen Bergman
title: Cease-Fire Talks Between Israel and Hamas Gain Momentum, Officials Say
description: While a deal was not yet in hand, a crack in the stalemate comes after Israel and Hezbollah reached a truce and President-elect Donald J. Trump ratcheted up the pressure for an agreement.
content: Cease-fire talks between Israel and Hamas to end the war in Gaza and free the remaining hostages are quietly advancing behind the scenes, mediators and officials say, after the Israel-Hezbollah truce in Lebanon and pressure from President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: The Most Popular Recipes of 2024
description: You loved these recipes. Now see what made our Top 25.
content: Well, that was fast: It was January, we blinked and now it’s December. Quite a bit has happened in the last 300 or so days, and the team at New York Times Cooking created, tested and published about 1,000 delicious recipes to help you eat well through it all. Your favorites — the dishes you added to your rotation, the meals your kids actually (OK, mostly) ate, the dinners you were excited to cook — are below. Once again, the three Cs (comfort, convenience and chicken) were king. You can view the complete list of our 50 most popular recipes here. Find one you haven’t cooked yet, and try it tonight. Happy cooking and Happy New Year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Lara Trump to Step Down as R.N.C. Co-Chair Amid Florida Senate Speculation
description: The daughter-in-law of President-elect Donald J. Trump, Ms. Trump gave no indication of her next move. Senator Marco Rubio’s seat would become open if he’s confirmed as secretary of state.
content: Lara Trump, whose name has been floated to fill a possible Senate vacancy in Florida, is stepping down as co-chair of the Republican National Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Byman
title: Al-Assad’s Syria Was Brutal. Will What Comes Next Be Better?
description: It is hard not to worry that Syrians’ sense of deep relief today could be followed by a new set of horrors tomorrow.
content: It is hard not to rejoice while watching images of ecstatic Syrians toppling statues from the regime of the deposed dictator Bashar al-Assad and hearing the shouts of joy of prisoners, many of whom may have been tortured and starved, released from his dungeons. Mr. al-Assad’s Syria was brutal for the regime’s opponents, and 13 years of civil war and a kleptocratic regime made life dangerous and miserable for ordinary Syrians. In addition to striking a blow for human freedom, Mr. al-Assad’s fall also removes an Iranian-backed, anti-American and anti-Israel dictator from the Middle East chessboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Daniel Berehulak
title: Road to Damascus Littered With Relics of Fallen Assad Government
description: Reporters for The New York Times entered Syria on Monday, finding remnants of former President Bashar al-Assad’s oppressive rule.
content: We arrived in Damascus early Monday, after passing surreal scenes on the highway leading into the city from Lebanon. Scattered across the main highway to the Syrian capital are newfound relics of the government of Bashar al-Assad whose oppressive rule has defined the country for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Art of the Gift: Kristen Arnett
description: The author keeps a list on her phone of gift ideas. “During the year, if someone close to me mentioned something that they really like or really want, I put a note in right then.”
content: Kristen Arnett, 43, is the New York Times best-selling author of “Mostly Dead Things” and “With Teeth.” Her next novel, “Stop Me If You’ve Heard This One,” is due to publish in March. She lives in Orlando, Fla. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: New York Taxpayers Could Get Refunds of Up to $500 Under Hochul Plan
description: The proposal, which Gov. Kathy Hochul intends to include in next year’s state budget, would send $3 billion in refunds to roughly 8.6 million New Yorkers.
content: Looking ahead to next year’s state budget and, perhaps, her re-election race the following year, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Monday proposed sending $3 billion in “inflation refund” checks to most taxpayers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia, Christina Goldbaum, Raja Abdulrahim, Robert Jimison, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Syria’s New Reality, and Trump Lays Out Aggressive Agenda
description: Plus, the end of the Eras Tour.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Eyes, Not Tech, Led Police to ‘Person of Interest’ in C.E.O. Killing
description: The key was not advanced facial recognition technology. An employee at a Pennsylvania McDonald’s reported the man after seeing a widely circulated image of the suspect.
content: In the end, it was the simple act of distributing photos — not sophisticated facial recognition technology — that led the police to a man they are calling a “person of interest” in the fatal shooting of a health care executive in Midtown Manhattan last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe, Bianca Pallaro, Jay Root and Benjamin Weiser
title: How a Criminal With Close Ties to China Became a New York Power Broker
description: John Chan was a Chinatown gangster before remaking himself into a powerful force in New York politics — one closely aligned with the Chinese Communist Party.
content: On a Monday in March, in the heart of China’s capital, more than 2,000 delegates of a rubber-stamp advisory body to the authoritarian government of President Xi Jinping gathered for their annual meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M. Gessen, Lydia Polgreen and Vishakha Darbha
title: The Power Struggle Behind Trans Youth Health Care
description: And why the debate over gender-affirming care could have far-reaching implications.
content: In this episode of “The Opinions,” the New York Times Opinion columnists Lydia Polgreen and M. Gessen discuss the historic Supreme Court case United States v. Skrmetti, its implications for gender-affirming care for minors in Tennessee and what it could mean for how the federal government interprets “equal rights” moving forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Resistance and Struggle in a Dance of Private Rites
description: A solo by the choreographer Bintou Dembélé, the first showing of her work in the United States, explored the crossover between hip-hop and diasporic African ritual.
content: When I asked the man if the seat next to him was taken, he didn’t even open his eyes. That’s when I first wondered whether he might not be just another member of the audience.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Dec. 9, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 9, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Grand Total: A Record $2 Billion
description: Over 21 months, the pop superstar’s culture-dominating stage show doubled the gross of its closest competitor, according to ticket sales figures confirmed for the first time.
content: For the last 21 months, Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour has been the biggest thing in music — a phenomenon that has engulfed pop culture, dominated news coverage and boosted local economies around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Dries Van Noten Names a New Dries Van Noten
description: Julian Klausner, who has been head of its women’s studio, is stepping into the founder’s shoes.
content: A new creative power structure in fashion is beginning to emerge. On Monday, five months after Dries Van Noten (the man) shocked the style world by retiring, Dries Van Noten (the brand) named Julian Klausner as its new creative director, elevating a longtime member of the design team to the top post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Suspect Is Charged in C.E.O.’s Murder After Arrest in Pennsylvania
description: Luigi Mangione was arrested after a tip from a McDonald’s in Altoona. On Monday night, Manhattan prosecutors charged him with murder.
content: The tipster’s call to the local police came in shortly after 9 a.m. Monday from a McDonald’s in western Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Thomas Fuller
title: Moderate Earthquake Rattles Reno and Lake Tahoe
description: Preliminary estimates showed that the quake had a magnitude of 5.8, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
content: Residents of Northern Nevada and the Lake Tahoe basin were rattled on Monday afternoon by an earthquake that struck southeast of Reno, Nev. Preliminary estimates showed that the quake had a magnitude of 5.8, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Leader of Polygamist Sect in Arizona Gets 50 Years in Child Sex Ring Case
description: Samuel R. Bateman, 48, of Colorado City, Ariz., who claimed to have more than 20 “wives” including 10 “brides” under 18, pleaded guilty in April to two felony conspiracy charges.
content: The self-proclaimed leader of a polygamist sect in Arizona who amassed more than 20 “wives,” including 10 “brides” under 18, was sentenced on Monday to 50 years in prison in connection with what prosecutors described as an interstate child sexual abuse ring, according to the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: How to Avoid Pickpockets and Street Scams
description: Staying aware, keeping your valuables close and employing “layers of security” are among the ways to improve your street savvy.
content: Street theft isn’t petty to a victim. Having your pocket picked or bags stolen can ruin your trip and your finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Tuesday Briefing: Syrian Rebels Rush to Establish Order
description: Plus, a lawsuit for trans rights in China.
content: The rebels who took over Damascus announced yesterday that a new government would begin work immediately, as millions of Syrians and the wider world struggled to process the stunning end to the Assad family’s decades-long reign. Rebel fighters took up positions outside public buildings and directed traffic in a show of their newly claimed authority. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller
title: The Most Memorable Things We Saw at Miami Art Week
description: And what the last art fairs of 2024 say about where the art world is going.
content: The art fair Art Basel Miami Beach, and the satellite events that have emerged around it, collectively known as Miami Art Week, have been held the first week of December every year since 2002, except in 2020 because of the pandemic. But even that year, Libbie Mugrabi, the ex-wife of the art dealer David Mugrabi, riding high from an enormous divorce settlement, threw a lavish dinner at the Faena Hotel. (“I can do whatever I want with it,” she told The New York Times of the payout. “And this is what I want to do.”) Last week, one gallery owner from New York summed up the purpose of the fair to me succinctly: “I need to make money,” he said. Miami is especially good for gauging the mood of the art business, and the direction it might be heading in. Prices at art auctions have been declining over the past two years, but a lot of people did indeed make money. And there was some evocative art on view, too. Below are a few takeaways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher and Joseph Bernstein
title: Man Arrested After C.E.O. Killing Showed Interest on Social Media in Self-Improvement
description: Figures like Andrew Huberman, Tim Urban and the Unabomber feature in posts shared by accounts that appear to belong to the man arrested on Monday.
content: The social media accounts that appear to belong to Luigi Mangione, the man the police have identified as a “strong person of interest” in the killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, seemed to show an interest in self-improvement, clean eating and critiques of contemporary technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Minnesota Vikings Find Unlikely Muse for Celebration Dance: ‘White Chicks’
description: Not everyone loved the 2004 film “White Chicks.” But 20 years later, some N.F.L. players are paying homage to it in the end zone.
content: If you don’t remember, “White Chicks” was a 2004 comedy in which the Black actors Marlon and Shawn Wayans donned heavy makeup to disguise themselves as white women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Comedian’s Path From Small-Town Tennessee to Breakout Fame
description: Leanne Morgan went from helping her husband sell mobile homes to sudden success in her 50s.
content: On many insomniac nights, when I’m trying to quiet the voices in my head, I listen to stand-up comics. I’ve been back and forth through Netflix’s roster: the blue-collar and the big city, the clean and the crude, the capital-W woke and the close-to-canceled, the ironists and the oafs, the oldies and the mere pups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Trump Says He Would Let ‘Dreamers’ Stay. But He Once Tried to Gut the Program.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s stance on the immigrants who were brought to the country illegally as children is filled with contradictions.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump has said he would look for ways to spare immigrants who were brought to the country illegally as children, known as Dreamers, from deportation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Council Sues Adams for Blocking Solitary Confinement Ban
description: The lawsuit charges that Mayor Eric Adams exceeded his authority when he declared a state of emergency to block a ban on the practice in city jails.
content: The New York City Council filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to force Mayor Eric Adams to carry out a law banning solitary confinement in city jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: A Contemporary Music Festival Trolls for Aesthetics’ Sake
description: The directors of the London Contemporary Music Festival discuss this year’s edition, the event’s 10th anniversary.
content: Recently, the London Contemporary Music Festival released a limited run of merchandise. There was a graphic T-shirt featuring the names of musicians whose creations have appeared at past festivals, plotted on a graph with two axes: the Y labeled “twee” to “brutal,” and the X “top” to “bottom.” Brian Ferneyhough was a brutal top, Cornelius Cardew a twee bottom, and Laurie Anderson was somewhere in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Easy-to-Assemble Ghost Guns Have Been a Major Issue in Gun Control
description: The weapons do not have serial numbers and are sold online as do-it-yourself kits, making them popular among criminals barred from buying ordinary guns.
content: The man held in the killing of a health care executive, arrested on firearms charges in Pennsylvania on Monday, possessed what investigators believe was a so-called ghost gun, said Joseph Kenny, the chief of detectives for the New York police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aryn Baker
title: Syria’s President Had Stocks of Chemical Weapons. What Happens to Them Now?
description: While experts believe that Syria has retained some stocks of chemical weapons, their quantities likely have been depleted and it would be hard for rogue actors to use them.
content: Rebels seized control of Syria’s capital on Sunday, ending the reign of Bashar al-Assad, who infamously used chemical weapons to kill thousands of his own citizens during the country’s 13-year-long civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Luigi Mangione, Suspect in C.E.O.’s Killing, Attended Elite Institutions
description: He grew up in Maryland, graduated from a private high school in Baltimore and went on to the University of Pennsylvania.
content: Luigi Mangione, 26, the man who was taken into custody Monday morning in Altoona, Pa., and identified as a suspect in the killing of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare in Midtown Manhattan last Wednesday, appears to have been a well-educated and well-traveled enthusiast of computer programming and gaming with an interest in self-improvement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Annie Karni
title: Ernst, Under MAGA Pressure, Signals Backing for Hegseth’s Pentagon Bid
description: Senator Joni Ernst, an Iowa Republican who is facing re-election in 2026, appeared less skeptical after President-elect Donald Trump’s supporters threatened her with political retribution.
content: Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, signaled on Monday that she would not oppose Pete Hegseth’s bid for defense secretary, hinting at a turnabout after days of hectoring and threats by President-elect Donald J. Trump’s hard-right supporters who threatened political retribution if she failed to fall into line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: Southern California Braces for Another ‘Particularly Dangerous’ Fire Forecast
description: Wildfire risk is high in Southern California, where little rain has fallen recently. The threat will skyrocket this week as offshore winds pick up.
content: Strong Santa Ana winds are expected to intensify the wildfire threat in Southern California early this week and create a “particularly dangerous situation” in Ventura and Los Angeles Counties, similar to circumstances in early November that helped fuel a significant wildfire, forecasters warned on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Regensdorf
title: How to Apply Makeup That Lasts
description: Advice from Tinashe, Justin Vivian Bond and Yadim.
content: In this season of back-to-back parties, there’s an extra premium on makeup that stays put. That need for longevity is something that stage performers — who must contend with sweat, bright lights and hurried costume changes — understand well. We asked three people familiar with those challenges about the products and techniques they rely on. Below, tips from Valentino Beauty’s global makeup artist, Yadim; the cabaret artist Justin Vivian Bond, whose show “Flakes” opens Dec. 12 at Joe’s Pub in New York; and the musician Tinashe, now on tour with her latest album, “Quantum Baby.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Carlotta Gall, Clare Toeniskoetter, Carlos Prieto, Rachelle Bonja, Lynsea Garrison, Patricia Willens, Ben Calhoun, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: Inside the Fall of Syria’s Brutal Dictator
description: Over the weekend, President Bashar al-Assad was ousted by rebel forces. What comes next?
content: Syria has been controlled by one family for more than half a century. It ruled by repression, devastation and violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellina Moore
title: ‘The Creep Tapes’ Finale, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: Mark Duplass reprises his serial killer role in a new series. And reality TV royalty, Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie, reunite.
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are broadcast live or available for streaming this week, Dec. 9 to Dec. 15. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: Nobel Laureates Urge Senate to Turn Down Kennedy’s Nomination
description: Elevating Mr. Kennedy to secretary of H.H.S. “would put the public’s health in jeopardy,” more than 75 laureates wrote.
content: More than 75 Nobel Prize winners have signed a letter urging senators not to confirm Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin, John Liu, Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle
title: China Opens Investigation Into Nvidia Over Potential Antitrust Violations
description: The move by Chinese regulators came a week after the Biden administration expanded curbs on the sale of advanced U.S. technology to China.
content: China’s antimonopoly regulator announced on Monday that it was investigating potential violations of antitrust law by Nvidia, the American company that makes a vast majority of the computer chips that power artificial intelligence systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Golden Globes 2025: The Full List of Nominees
description: The movies and TV series competing for the 82nd Golden Globe Awards. The ceremony will air on Jan. 5.
content: The nominations for the 82nd Golden Globes were announced Monday, and “Emilia Pérez” and “The Brutalist” are the top nominees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Century-Old Law’s Aftershocks Are Still Felt at the Supreme Court
description: In 1925, Congress let the justices choose the cases they would decide. That change “continues to prompt political contention and crisis,” a scholar argues.
content: Almost exactly a century ago, in February 1925, Chief Justice William Howard Taft persuaded Congress to grant the Supreme Court an extraordinary power: to pick which cases it would decide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Scrambles to Navigate Perils of a New Syria
description: The Biden administration is relying on Turkey to convey messages to Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which toppled Bashar al-Assad but is designated by the U.S. as a terrorist organization.
content: The Biden administration is scrambling to find ways to engage with groups in Syria and around the Middle East as victorious militias begin shaping the nation’s future after the toppling of President Bashar al-Assad, the longtime autocrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: permafrost
description: This word has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word permafrost has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 30 in “The Right Kind of Tipping Point” by David Gelles:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 9 Best Theater Moments of 2024
description: “The Outsiders,” “Sunset Boulevard” and “Ragtime” were among the productions with stage moments that stood out this year.
content: Climate protesters disrupting a performance of “An Enemy of the People,” the outdoor walking scene in “Sunset Boulevard” and the giggles prompted by a character’s reaction to a hunky celebrity’s glutes in “Hold On to Me Darling”: The rewards of live theater were aplenty this year. Here, nine other stage moments that especially stood out, listed chronologically. NICOLE HERRINGTON
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Should Lessons Based on the Bible Be Taught in Public Schools?
description: Texas has become the latest state to bring Christianity into the classroom. What is your reaction?
content: In June, Louisiana passed a mandate that the Ten Commandments be displayed in every public classroom. Days later, Oklahoma’s state superintendent directed every public school to teach the Bible. And last month, Texas education officials approved a new elementary school curriculum that includes lessons based on the Bible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Andy Newman
title: Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting Had a Manifesto, Police Say
description: The handwritten document found with Luigi Mangione criticized health care companies for prioritizing profits and conveyed “ill will toward corporate America,” according to the authorities.
content: The man who was arrested on Monday in connection with the killing of the health care executive Brian Thompson was found with a handwritten document that spoke to his “motivation and mind-set,” Jessica Tisch, the commissioner of the New York Police Department, said at a news conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Explosion at Fuel Depot Near Florence Kills at Least Two
description: Officials said it would take time to determine the cause of the explosion. At least 26 people were injured in the blast.
content: At least two people were killed and another 26 injured Monday in an explosion at a fuel depot on the outskirts of Florence, according to city officials and the company that ran the facility. The cause of the explosion had not yet been determined, the company said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Trump Tests Ethical Boundaries With Branded Merch. (And All Sales Are Final.)
description: Everything around President-elect Donald J. Trump has become something to monetize, including a moment of comity with Jill Biden at Notre-Dame over the weekend.
content: Donald J. Trump learned a long time ago that photo opportunities could get him attention and that slapping his name on everything from skyscrapers to steaks could make him money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: ‘Person of Interest’ in C.E.O. Shooting Has Background in Games Industry
description: Luigi Mangione was passionate about game development and programming from a young age, teaching himself to code in high school.
content: The digital footprint of Luigi Mangione, the man the police are considering a “strong person of interest” in the killing of a UnitedHealthcare executive last week, indicates that he has a background in the technology and video games industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Iran’s Very Bad Year
description: We explain the country’s annus horribilis.
content: Most questions about Syria’s future don’t have clear answers. Will the Islamist rebels who have taken over the country create a harsh Taliban-style government? Or do the rebels’ recent hints of moderation point toward something gentler? The situation remains uncertain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain’s Flawed Jobs Reports Leave Economists ‘Second-Guessing’
description: Officials are grappling with an incomplete picture of Britain’s labor market as the national statistics agency strains to improve data quality.
content: An essential ingredient in economic policymaking, from interest rates to government spending, is reliable data. But government officials, economists and other number crunchers in Britain are expressing deepening concern over a long-running issue with a data set used to understand a crucial area: the country’s jobs market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Anusha Bayya
title: Daniel Penny Is Acquitted in Death of Jordan Neely on Subway
description: Mr. Penny choked Mr. Neely in a minutes-long struggle on the floor of an F train. The case reflected the pathologies of post-pandemic New York.
content: Daniel Penny, a former Marine who choked a fellow subway rider on an uptown F train last year, was acquitted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide on Monday, ending a case that had come to exemplify New York City’s post-pandemic struggles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Surprise Advance to Damascus, Captured on Video
description: Bashar Al-Assad’s grip over Syria was visible everywhere in the capital. It was all dismantled in less than 24 hours.
content: A brazen nighttime prison release. Presidential posters set on fire. Children playing in the halls of a building once controlled by the former regime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Mets Stole Juan Soto From the Yankees. Who’s the Big Spender Now?
description: The Yankees didn’t just lose a superstar; they lost him to the Mets. Is the balance of power shifting in New York?
content: Did you feel the ground shake Sunday night? Did New York suddenly tilt from the Bronx down to Queens?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Claims Credit for al-Assad’s Ouster, but Sees Risk in His Absence
description: For Israel’s leaders, Bashar al-Assad’s downfall was made possible by their recent assaults on Hezbollah, Iran and Syria, all of which weakened the Iran-backed axis.
content: For the past year, Israel’s allies and enemies pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to limit his attacks on Iran and its partners in Lebanon and Syria, hoping to avoid a regional escalation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: With Syria in Flux, Turkish Forces Attack U.S.-Backed Forces
description: Rebels supported by Turkish air power fired on a Kurdish-controlled city in northern Syria, pitting proxies of the U.S. and Turkey — NATO allies — against each other.
content: The Turkish military fired on U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in northern Syria this weekend, a war monitoring group and a spokesman for the Kurdish group said on Sunday, illuminating the tangle of competing interests and alliances in Syria in the wake of the government’s collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons and Isabelle Taft
title: Can Trump End Birthright Citizenship? Not Easily.
description: The president-elect has revived his wish to do away with automatic citizenship for anyone born in the United States. The Constitution stands in his way.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump has revived talk of abolishing birthright citizenship — the guarantee, rooted in common law and enshrined in the Constitution for more than 150 years, that anyone born in the United States is automatically an American citizen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jay-Z Sued Lawyer as a ‘Celebrity’ John Doe Before Assault Accusation
description: Lawyers for the rapper accused Tony Buzbee of attempting to “extort exorbitant sums” from him by making false assault claims.
content: Several weeks before Jay-Z was accused in a lawsuit of raping a minor with Sean Combs, he received a letter from a plaintiff’s lawyer threatening to “immediately file” a “public lawsuit” against him unless he agreed to resolve the matter through mediation for money, his lawyers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Ol’ Blue Eyes
description: The sisters have a terrifying vision. Desmond gives a terrifying display of his power and loyalty. Any connection?
content: Two blue lights shine in the darkness, like the eyes of an insectoid machine. Guttural sounds, like speech in a language not yet invented, accompany them, but only for a second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Judge Denies Nadine Menendez’s Request to Postpone Trial Further
description: Ms. Menendez, the wife of New Jersey’s former senator, is scheduled to stand trial on Jan. 21, eight days before her husband is expected to be sentenced for taking bribes.
content: Nadine Menendez arrived at federal court in Manhattan on Monday without her husband, New Jersey’s disgraced former U.S. senator, her right arm in a sling and her face largely covered by a pink surgical mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: At the Kennedy Center, a Send-Off to Biden and Questions About the Future
description: A bipartisan crowd honored Francis Ford Coppola, the Grateful Dead, Bonnie Raitt, Arturo Sandoval and the Apollo Theater. Some wondered if Donald J. Trump would attend next year.
content: The arrival of the president to the center box is typically a pro forma affair each year at the Kennedy Center Honors. But President Biden’s arrival on Sunday night carried the tinge of a Washington on the verge of change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Flying at Extremes May Hurt Navy Pilots’ Brains
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 9, 2024.
content: “Those turns look graceful from the ground, but inside the cockpit you are vibrating like crazy and fighting to stay conscious.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Emilia Pérez’ Tops Golden Globe Nominations
description: The movie received 10 nods, leading the field. Angelina Jolie, Timothée Chalamet, Pamela Anderson and Zendaya drew acting nominations.
content: The point of the Golden Globes has become clearer in recent years: It’s a cash register masquerading as an awards show — an opportunity to sell advertising, promote winter movies and flog designer gowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Quantum Computing Inches Closer to Reality After Another Google Breakthrough
description: Google unveiled an experimental machine capable of tasks that a traditional supercomputer could not master in 10 septillion years. (That’s older than the universe.)
content: In 2019, a team of Google researchers said they had built a machine capable of performing tasks that were not possible with traditional supercomputers. They described this machine, called a quantum computer, as a turning point in the evolution of information technology.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Expanding the Laws on Assisted Dying
description: Readers discuss the British vote on the issue and urge actions in the U.S. Also: Safeguarding our food; taxing cow burps in Denmark; a crossword tale.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: In Syria, an Image of Rebellion Embodied in a Hoodie
description: The quotidian uniforms of Syrian rebels, as they appeared on television, draws a powerful contrast to the image of President Bashar al-Assad.
content: The rebels appeared on Syrian state television over the weekend in puffer jackets and sweatshirts. One wore what appeared to be a trucker hat. A man in the center — the group’s appointed spokesman — wore a black hoodie as he addressed the Syrian people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: Curbside Composting: What to Do and What Not to Do
description: New York City has extended its curbside composting program to all five boroughs. Here’s how to sort through the heap of rules and guidelines.
content: This fall, New York City expanded its curbside composting program to all five boroughs, good news for New Yorkers looking to lessen their environmental footprint. As part of the program, residents must now separate their food scraps and yard waste from other garbage and place them in a bin for pickup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Map: 5.8-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Nevada
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Chodosh
title: The Killings of Young Mothers
description: For women under 25, getting pregnant more than doubles their risk of homicide.
content: For women under 25, getting pregnant more than doubles their risk of homicide.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Letter From Nobel Laureates Urging That Mr. Kennedy Not be Confirmed
description: More than 75 laureates have written an open letter describing Mr. Kennedy’s selection for H.H.S. secretary as detrimental to public health.
content: More than 75 laureates have written an open letter describing Mr. Kennedy’s selection for H.H.S. secretary as detrimental to public health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Federico Rios
title: How Netflix Made Magic Look Real in ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’
description: The first-ever screen adaptation will be released this week — a feat even the author didn’t think possible. We traveled to the set in Colombia to see how it was done.
content: The first-ever screen adaptation will be released this week — a feat even the author didn’t think possible. We traveled to the set in Colombia to see how it was done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Winter Holidays and Popular Books of the Season?
description: Celebrate the literature of this festive month with with a five-question quiz that comes with its own reading list.
content: Celebrate the literature of this festive month with with a five-question quiz that comes with its own reading list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: 58 Jazz Luminaries Assembled for This Photo. Only One Remains.
description: Art Kane’s “Harlem 1958” gathered giants of the music. Sonny Rollins, 94, looks back at the historic picture.
content: Art Kane’s “Harlem 1958” gathered giants of the music. Sonny Rollins, 94, looks back at the historic picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nader Ibrahim and Haley Willis
title: Crowds Go to Syria’s Sednaya Prison In Search of Loved Ones
description: Rebel forces released many detainees from the notorious Sednaya military prison in Damascus. The government complex has a long history of human rights abuses under the rule of fallen President Bashar al-Assad.
content: Rebel forces released many detainees from the notorious Sednaya military prison in Damascus. The government complex has a long history of human rights abuses under the rule of fallen President Bashar al-Assad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘Strong Person of Interest’ Is Arrested in Health Care C.E.O.’s Shooting
description: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested on gun charges and for questioning in connection with last week’s killing of a health insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan.
content: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested on gun charges and for questioning in connection with last week’s killing of a health insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: ‘We Came Here Gloating’: Syrians Loot Assad’s Palace
description: Thrilled by the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, Syrians took furniture and appliances from his official residence. Some posed for photos.
content: Thrilled by the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, Syrians took furniture and appliances from his official residence. Some posed for photos.
